newsitem.title: JAPAN: TIFFE Euroyen futures up in sympathy with JGBs.
newsitem.headline: TIFFE Euroyen futures up in sympathy with JGBs.

text.p: The key June three-month Euroyen deposit rate futures contract on TIFFE ended Tuesday's day session higher in sympathy with soaring Japanese government bond (JGBs) futures, traders said.
The June hit 99.25 in the afternoon, a high for the June contract, following a jump in the key December JGB futures contract to 123.96, the highest for any benchmark JGB contract listed on the TSE.
"The underlying sentiment is strong due to higher JGBs. The market's perception is that a low interest rate environment will continue," said a trader at a Japanese city bank.
In the interbank call market, the key unsecured overnight rate was traded at 0.49 percent, up from 0.48 percent on Monday.
The Bank of Japan maintained a neutral stance in this morning's money market operation.
Demand for funds, however, remained strong, with traders citing private-sector salary payments as a factor causing market tightness.
About 130 billion yen worth of the key three-month certificates of deposit (CDs) were issued at 0.52 percent, as were about 30 billion yen worth of one-month CDs at 0.49 percent.
Two-month CDs were offered at 0.50 percent. All rates were unchanged from Monday.

Interest rate swap (IRS) rates were lower following the JGB futures' rally. One-year IRS was at 0.61/65 percent, down from Monday's 0.63/67 percent. Two-year IRS was quoted at 0.92/96 percent, down from 0.96/1.00 percent on Monday.
